courses.subject: KORE
courses.title: Korean I

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 804
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 804
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 804

courses.description: This course invites students without prior knowledge of Korean to explore the basic features of the Korean language. Supported by audiovisual aids, students will receive intensive practice in spoken and written Korean through interactive class work, homework and online exercises. They will become familiar with the basic concepts of Korean grammar and learn how to interact in some simple everyday situations.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken KORE2000,2001,2050(1010),3000,3001,3002,3050 or 3051
courses.learning_outcomes: At the end of the course, students will be able to speak, read and write simple Han Geul (Korean writing system) having familiarity with current Korean society and its culture. They will be able to speak about topics such as everyday greetings, asking and giving information, shopping.
courses.course_syllabus:
Course Content: The course will cover Unit 1 – 5 of the textbook “Active Korean 1”
Lesson
Speech acts
Grammar
Unit 1
Hangeul
Introduction to ‘Han geul’
About Korea
History of the language
Consonants and Vowels
- vowels and consonants
- Diphthongs / Aspirated and forced consonants
- Some pronunciation rules
- Syllable structure
- Sentence structure
Unit 2
Greetings & Introduction
Greetings & Introductions
Introducing people (jobs, nationalities)
Asking the names of thing
- P- Basic sentence structure
- Subject marker -이/가
- Topic/Contrast marker -은/는
- Polite ‘Verb-‘be’ ending -예요/이에요& its negation: -이/가 아니에요
Unit3
Restaurant
Expressions used at restaurants
Counting things (Native Korean numbers)
Ordering at a restaurant
- V(으)세요 (To use honorific suffix)
- N 주세요 (“Give me N, please”)
- Measure Nouns (-개/명/장/잔/권…)
Unit4
Shopping
Expressions related to shopping
Buying things in a store
Talking about the location
- N이/가 A(Subject marker used with A)
N이/가 있어요/ 없어요
- 이거/저거/그거
- Numbers (Sino-Number)
- Marker also, too: -도
- Object marker -을/를
Unit 5
Daily life
Questions related to daily life
Talking about schedule
One’s likes and dislikes
Telling time
Telling days of the week
- A/V-아/어/여요(Informal Verb-ending)
- N 을/를 (Object Marker)
- N 에 가다/오다(go /come to somewhere)
- 안 A/V (Negation of A/V)
- 못 V : can not V
- V고 (and)/ V지만 (but)
Conjunctions: 그리고, 그러나, 그런데 그렇지만, 그래서, 하지만, 왜냐하면
courses.feedback_evaluation: Our language programme highly values students’ feedback and comments and is happy to use them for reflection on our teaching and improvement. Students are very welcome to provide comments and feedback on the course any time to their course teacher or the course level coordinator through email or in personal conversation. In addition, students’ feedbacks will be collected in the middle of the term through an open-end questionnaire and the teacher will discuss the feedbacks in class and make improvements if necessary. The course will also follow the university’s course evaluation exercise at the end of the term, and students’ feedbacks will be used for future course planning and teaching.
courses.required_readings:
Required textbook:
* Active Korean 1 2006. Language Education Institute Seoul National University
The book is available at Swindon University Bookstore.
* Sogang New Korean 1A 2008. Korean Language Education Center, Sogang University, Korea.
(Used as Supplementary, Students are not required to purchase)

courses.subject: KORE
courses.title: Invitation to Korean Online
courses.description: [This course is offered via asynchronous online mode. Students should register the course via KEEP, a CUHK eLearning platform where the course materials are uploaded.]This online course invites students without prior knowledge of Korean to explore the basic features of the Korean language and topics of Korean culture and society. Supported by audiovisual aids, students will learn basic concepts of Korean grammar and vocabularies for simple daily communication. This course serves as a taster for students who may consider taking Korean courses in the future.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for students who have taken KORE1000,2000,2001,2050,3000,3001,3002,3050or3051
From 2023-24, students can only earn up to 2 units of these courses: CLCP1001,CLCP1101,CLCC1001,CLCC1101,JASP1350,HKSL1001,SPAN1001,GERM1001,KORE1001,FREN1001
courses.course_syllabus:
Course Content
Unit
Topic
Expressions
Culture
Unit 1
Greetings and Introducing
인사와
소개
Greetings
Introducing
Greetings when meeting someone new: “안녕하세요?”, “처음 뵙겠습니다.”, “잘 부탁드립니다.”
Goodbyes: “안녕히 가세요.”, “안녕히 계세요.”
Introducing one’s name: “저는 N입니다.”
Talking about where someone is from: “N에서 왔습니다.”
Vocabulary: country/city/university names
Numbers: (1) Sino-Korean numbers
Talking about someone’s phone number
Numbers: (2) Native Korean numbers
Talking about someone’s age
Introduction to the Korean Programme at CU
The most used messaging apps in Korea
The unique age-calculating-system in Korea
Unit 2
Food
음식
Ordering at a restaurant
Ordering at a coffee shop
Asking and expressing prices
Vocabulary: food names
Expressions used at a restaurant:
(1) “Excuse me.”: “여기요.”, “아주머니/ 이모님”
(2) “Give me N, please.”: “N주세요.”
(3) “More”: “더”
Vocabulary: expressions describing taste and flavor such as맛있어요, 맛없어요, 매워요, 짜요, 달아요, etc.
Vocabulary: drink names
“N and N’”: N하고 N’
Counting units: 잔, 조각, etc.
Item + Native Korean number + counting unit
Asking for prices: “얼마예요?”
Expressing prices: Sino-Korean Numbers + 원
“Give me this, please.”: “이거 주세요.”
“Here you are.”: “여기 있어요.”
Favorite Korean and exotic foods chosen by foreigners
Korean song that shows Koreans’ love for coffee: ‘10cm’의 <아메리카노>
Convenience stores & traditional markets in Korea
Unit 3
School Life
학교
생활
School Life
Hobby
Likes and Dislikes
Vocabulary: university building names
Expressing destinations: [place]에 가요/와요
Informal verb-ending: -아/어/여요
Negation: 안 V
Expressing likes: N 좋아해요
Verb nominalization: V-는 거
Joining University clubs
University Festivals
Types of gathering
Unit 4
Living in Korea
한국
생활
Planning a trip
Big cities in Korea
Tourists attractions in Seoul
“Shall we do V”: “V-(으)ㄹ까요?”
“Want to do V”: “V-고 싶어요.”
“Give it a try”: “-아/어 보세요.”
Adjectives: 어때요?, 유명해요, 멋있어요, 재미있어요, etc.
“Please do V (for me)”: “V-아/어/여 주세요.”
Tenses in Korean: present, past and future. e.g., 해요, 했어요, and할 거예요
Korean monetary unit “Won”
Special products/food in different places
Fun activities to do in Seoul
courses.feedback_evaluation: Our language programme highly values students’ feedback and comments and is happy to use them for reflection on our teaching and improvement. Students are very welcome to provide comments and feedback on the course any time to the course coordinator of the Department of Linguistics and Modern Languages. An online course evaluation exercise will be conducted at the end of the course, and students’ feedbacks will be used for future course planning and teaching.

courses.subject: KORE
courses.title: Gateway to Korea
courses.description: This course examines Korean history, language and culture from interdisciplinary and cross-cultural perspectives and makes systematic comparisons between Korea and Hong Kong.
courses.course_syllabus:
KORE1100
Topic
Description
Remarks
Week 1
Introduction of the
C
ourse
Korean History:
P
art I
A brief introduction to Korean history: Prehistoric and Antiquity period, Three Kingdoms Era, and North and South States.
Week 2
Korean History:
P
art II
A brief introduction to Korean history: Goryeo, Joseon, and Modern history.
Week 3
Customs of Korea
Customs of Korea;
Festivals and leisure life.
Week 4
Korean language
Introduction to language and comparison to other languages.
Start of team presentation
Week 5
Regions of Korea
Dialects, customs, and cuisine of the eight regions in Korea.
Week 6
Religions in Korea
Major religions in Korea: Buddhism, Confucianism, and Christianity;
Folk religions and new religions in Korea: Shamanism, Unification Church, etc.
Week 7
Traditional
C
ulture: Part I
Performing arts.
Week 8
Traditional
C
ulture: Part II
Architecture and fine arts.
Week 9
Contemporary
P
op
C
ulture: Part I
TV drama, K-pop, and movies.
Week 10
Contemporary
P
op
C
ulture: Part II
The Korean Wave: Hallyu.
Submission of reflection paper
Week 11
Korean
P
olitics
North Korea and South Korea;
The relationship between South Korea and Japan;
The relationship between South Korea and China.
Week 12
Korean society: Part I
Contemporary issues on Korean society.
Week 13
Korean society: Part II
Contemporary issues on Korean society.
Week 14
Final examination
courses.feedback_evaluation: Our language programme highly values students’ feedback for enhancement of teaching and teaching quality. Qualitative feedback from students will be collected in the mid-term course and teaching evaluation (CTE) for teacher’s reference and or self-reflection. A term-end CTE will be conducted to collect both quantitative and qualitative feedback from students. Students are also welcome to give their comments on the course to the course teacher or course level coordinator at any time.
courses.required_readings:
Horlyck, Charlotte and Pettid, Michael J. (2014). Death, Mourning, and the Afterlife in Korea: From Ancient to Contemporary Times. Hawaii: University of Hawaii Press.
Jackson, Ben and Koehler, Robert. (2012). Korean Architecture: Breathing with Nature. Seoul: Seoul Selection.
Kendall, Laurel. (2010). Shamans, Nostalgias, and the IMF: South Korean Popular Religion in Motion. Hawaii: University of Hawaii Press.
Kim, Amber Hyun Jung. (2012). Korea's Natural Wonders: Exploring Korea's Landscapes. Seoul: Seoul Selection.
Koehler, Rober. (2012). Religion in Korea: Harmony and Coexistence. Seoul: Seoul Selection.
Koehler, Robert. (2012). Korean Ceramics: The Beauty of Natural Forms. Seoul: Seoul Selection.
Lee, Iksop and Ramsey, S. Robert. (2001). The Korean Language. New York: State University of New York Press.
Sohn, Ho-min. (2005). Korean Language in Culture and Society. Hawaii: University of Hawaii Press.
The Association of Korean History Teachers. (2010). A Korean History for International Readers: What Do Koreans Talk About Their Own History and Culture?. Seoul: Humanist Publishing Group Inc.

courses.subject: KORE
courses.title: Korean II

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 402
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 402
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 402

courses.description: Building on the knowledge acquired in KORE1000, this course aims to further develop students’ ability to communicate in Korean in various everyday situations. It also seeks to give students a taste of Korean culture and invites them to explore cultural differences. Through intensive practice students will develop more confidence in interacting in Korean while further expanding and solidifying their understanding of the basic grammar and pronunciation patterns.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for students who have taken KORE2001,2050(1010),3000,3001,3002,3050(2010) or 3051(3010)
Prerequisite: KORE1000 (1001)
courses.learning_outcomes: The student should be able to master the basic communication skills such as talking about daily activities and habit, relating past events, asking for direction and location, using public transportation and making a phone call.
courses.course_syllabus:
Course Content: The course will cover Unit 6 – 9 of the textbook “Active Korean 1”
Lesson
Speech acts
Grammar
Unit 6
Time
Talking about daily life
Expressing negation
Expressing days of the week
Telling the time when something happens
- Describing a person or a thing
- Linking two sentences
S-지만 S’, S-고 S’
- Time : _시 _분
- N에,에서
- 안 A/V and 못A/V
Unit 7
Appointment
Making suggestions
Giving date
Talking about something you did in the past
Making appointment
- 을/ㄹ까요?
- Past tense
- 까지
- 시간, 분
- 월, 요일
Unit 8
Locations and Directions
Giving the location of an item
Asking for and giving directions
Asking how long it takes to the destination
Asking how to take subway line
- N이/가 있어요/ 없어요
- 위/아래/앞/뒤/옆/안
- (으)로 가다/오다
- 까지
- 에서
Unit 9
Phone call
Telephone conversation
Expressing an action in progress
Expressing the politeness
Expressing the future and the supposition
- v
- 
이지요? (Ask to confirm the statement)
- v-아/어/여 주다 (polite offer)
- v-고 있다
- ㄹ/을 거예요
- Honorific suffix: -(으)시
- Adjectives

Students are very welcome to provide comments and feedback on the course any time to their course teacher or the course level coordinator through email or in personal conversation. In addition, students’ feedbacks will be collected in the middle of the term through an open-end questionnaire and the teacher will discuss the feedbacks in class and make improvements if necessary. The course will also follow the university’s course evaluation exercise at the end of the term, and students’ feedbacks will be used for future course planning and teaching.

courses.subject: KORE
courses.title: Korean III
courses.description: This course aims to further enhance students’ communication skills in the four language domains listening, speaking, reading and writing. Students are expected to communicate confidently in a wider range of social interactions including more formal situations and simple professional contexts as well as reporting past events and sharing experience. At the end of this course, students will have completed a proficiency level comparable to level 1 of the Test of Proficiency in Korean (TOPIK).
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1.Not for students who have taken KORE3000,3001,3002,3050(2010) or 3051(3010)
2.Prerequisite: KORE2000 (1002) or 2050 (1010)
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, students should be able to
(1)improve their basic communication skills with expanded vocabulary, expressions and grammar.
(2)know how to address strangers or staff with questions and requests using the polite formal verb endings.
(3)be more accustomed to Korean traditional and modern culture and social life.
courses.course_syllabus:
Course Content: The course will cover unit 1 – 5 of the textbook “Active Korean 2”
Lesson
Speech acts
Grammar
Unit 1
Family
Expressions related to introducing family members :
talking about relations of family members and one’s seniors/elders
Using personal pronouns
N의N’ (possessive form)
N(이)세요 (identification of the subject)
누구 (who)
A/V-(으)세요/-(으)셨어요
(honorific identification of the subject)
무슨N (what kind of N)
Unit 2
Transportation
Expressions when using transportation:
Explaining how to get home using public transportation
Asking and answering how to get to somewhere/where to get off and how long it takes
Talking about what one should do
N에서N’을/를 타다 (get on a transportation in somewhere)
N에서 내리다 (get off at a place)
N에서N’(으)로 갈아타다 (transfer into another transportation at a place)
N을/를 타고 가다/오다 (go/come by a transportation)
‘ㄷ’ irregular verbs
Unit 3
Reason
Expressions needed when giving excuses:
Talking about what one cannot or could not do
Making an appointment
Giving a reason/two or more alternatives
못V ( cannot do V)
A/V-아/어/여서 (Because……..)
‘ㅂ’ irregular adjectives
N (이)라서 (Because N is N’)
N(이)나 N’ (either N or N’)
Unit 4
Post Office
Expressions needed at the post office:
Sending a parcel
Talking about conditions
Telling what’s inside
Telling what to do in each situation
V-ㄹ/을 거예요(future tense/to make a supposition)
N(으)로 (by means of N)
A/V-(으)면 (if…A/V…)
N한테 (to a person ( recipient))
Unit 5
Reservations
Expressions when making reservations:
Talking about possibility or ability
Buying tickets
Describing types of room when making reservations
Discussing length of time
V-ㄹ/을 수 있다 (can/ be able to V )
A-ㄴ/은데요/V-고 싶다 (expressions for wanting)
N 동안 (during N)
N부터 (from N : when defining a time or distance)

Students are very welcome to provide comments and feedback on the course any time to their course teacher or the course level coordinator through email or in personal conversation. In addition, students’ feedbacks will be collected in the middle of the term through an open-end questionnaire and the teacher will discuss the feedbacks in class and make improvements if necessary. The course will also follow the university’s course evaluation exercise at the end of the term, and students’ feedbacks will be used for future course planning and teaching.

courses.subject: KORE
courses.title: Korean I & II
courses.description: This is a summer intensive Korean language course for beginners, covering the full syllabus of KORE1000 and 2000.
courses.learning_outcomes: At the end of the course, students will be able to speak, read and write simple Han Geul (Korean writing system) having familiarity with current Korean society and its culture. They will be able to speak on topics such as everyday greetings, asking and giving information, shopping, telling date and time, fining locations and so forth.

Students are very welcome to provide comments and feedback on the course any time to their course teacher or the course level coordinator through email or in personal conversation. courses.subject: KORE
courses.title: Korean IV
courses.description: This course aims at increasing students’ communicative fluency in oral and written Korean. Using a variety of classroom activities and multimedia, students will build up their competence in the four language domains listening, speaking, reading and writing. Through intensive practice they will be able to communicate in a wide range of social situations with the appropriate awareness of the pragmatic rules involved. Students receive guidance in the process of composing longer texts displaying a range of registers and styles relating to past, present and future events.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1.Not for students who have taken KORE3001,3002,3050(2010) or 3051(3010)
2.Prerequisite: KORE2001
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, students should be able to
(1)improve the overall communication skills with enlarged linguistic knowledge
(2)Along with the oral practice, students will improve writing skill adequately with written verb-ending form
(3)be more accustomed to Korean culture and society
courses.course_syllabus:
Course Content: The course will cover unit 6 – 9 of the textbook “Active Korean 2”
Lesson
Speech acts
Grammar
Unit 6
Family
Expressions related to etiquette

courses.subject: KORE
courses.title: Korean V
courses.description: This course focuses on the further development of communication skills in Korean with emphasis on the expression of personal views and the training of argumentative strategies. The course will also engage students in critical reflections on various aspects of life in Korean and their own social environment. Students will be guided to analyze various types of data to support their views. They will learn how to express their wishes and aspirations using the appropriate registers.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1.Not for students who have taken KORE3002 or 3051 (3010) 
2.Pre-requisite: KORE3000 (2002) or 3050 (2010)

courses.subject: KORE
courses.title: Korean VI
courses.description: This course builds on the knowledge acquired through previous Korean language courses. It aims at leading students to a proficiency level comparable to the threshold from level 2 to level 3 of the Test of Proficiency in Korean (TOPIK). To achieve this goal, students will be encouraged to work project-based through independent or collaborative work with their peers. At the end of this course students will have mastered the most important grammar features of Korean and be able to communicate effectively in a wide range of everyday situations and a number of professional contexts. They will be able to use their oral and written language skills to relate to, reflect on and analyze past and current issues involving the Korean society.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for students who have taken KORE3051 (3010). 
Prerequisite: KORE3001.
courses.course_syllabus: This course builds on the knowledge acquired through previous Korean language courses. It aims at leading students to a proficiency level comparable to the threshold from level 2 to level 3 of the Test of Proficiency in Korean (TOPIK). To achieve this goal, students will be encouraged to work project-based through independent or collaborative work with their peers. At the end of this course students will have mastered the most important grammar features of Korean and be able to communicate effectively in a wide range of everyday situations and a number of professional contexts. They will be able to use their oral and written language skills to relate to, reflect on and analyze past and current issues involving the Korean society.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Our programme highly values students’ feedback and comments and is happy to use them for reflection on our teaching and improvement. Students are very welcome to provide comments and feedback on the course any time to their course teacher or the course level coordinator through email or in personal conversation. In addition, students’ feedbacks will be collected in the middle of the term through an open-end questionnaire and the teacher will discuss the feedbacks in class and make improvements if necessary. The course will also follow the university’s course evaluation exercise at the end of the term, and students’ feedbacks will be used for future course planning and teaching.

• Seoul University Korean Language Center. ‘Active Korean’. Course book with Audio CD & its Work book
• Sogang University Korean Language Center. ‘Sogang Korean’. Course book with Audio CD & its Work book
• Ewha University Korean Language Center. ‘Ewha Korean’. Course book with Audio CD & its Work book

courses.subject: KORE
courses.title: Sounds of Korean

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 405
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 405

courses.description: This course introduces the phonetic system of the Korean language. Supported by audiovisual aids, students will understand the sound of the vowels and consonants, the pronunciation rules and the intonations in different contexts of the Korean language. The articulation of some Korean sounds that are more difficult for Chinese speakers will also be examined. Through interactive classroom learning activities, students’ accuracy of Korean pronunciation will be enhanced.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Prerequisites: KORE3000,3001,3002,3050 or 3051
Not for students who have taken KORE3100 in 2nd term 2018-19 and 1st term 2019-20
courses.course_syllabus:
Topic
Content
Vowels
and
Consonants
Vowels
Single-vowels: ㅏ, ㅓ, ㅗ, ㅜ, ㅡ, ㅣ, ㅔ, ㅐ
Double-vowels: ㅘ, ㅝ, ㅟ, ㅚ, ㅞ, ㅙ / ㅑ, ㅕ, ㅛ, ㅠ, ㅖ, ㅒ, ㅢ
Consonants
Sounds of basic consonants: ㅁ, ㅂ, ㄴ, ㄷ, ㄹ, ㅅ, ㅈ, ㄱ, ㅇ, ㅎ
Aspiration: ㅋ, ㅌ, ㅍ, ㅊ
Glottal tension: ㄲ, ㄸ, ㅃ, ㅆ, ㅉ
Syllable-final consonants
Single-final consonants: [ㄱ], [ㄴ], [ㄷ], [ㄹ], [ㅁ], [ㅂ], [ㅇ]
Double-final consonants
Pronunciation Rules
Linking
: 한국어[한구거], 앉아요[안자요], 좋아요[조아요] etc.
Glottalization
: 학교[학꾜], 앉다[안따], 할 수[쑤] 있다, 여권[여꿘], etc.
Nasalization
: 박물관[방물관], 음료수[음뇨수], etc.
Aspiration
: 어떻게[어떠케], etc.
Lateralization
: 설날[설랄], etc.
Insertion of ‘
ㄴ
’
: 무슨 일[무슨닐], etc.
Intonation
Intonation of statements
Intonation of questions
Intonation of propositive sentences
Intonation of imperative sentences
Intonation of exclamational sentences

courses.subject: KORE
courses.title: Korean Conversation
courses.description: This course provides students with opportunity to develop their oral proficiency in Korean. Supported by teacher’s guidance and audiovisual materials, students will practice spoken Korean intensively in diverse sociocultural settings through interactive class work and homework. Preassigned readings before the class enhance students’ reading skills and understanding the background of each discussion session. They will practice speaking in a variety of speech styles, from the most casual dialogues to formal group discussions. Students will explore how to develop communication skills more appropriately in various social contexts in this process.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, students should be able to
(1) understand the different methods of communication that suits each different social context and improve their overall speaking proficiency
(2) use the most culture-appropriate Korean vocabulary and expressions.
(3) explore communication strategies to become better communicators
courses.course_syllabus:
Topic
Contents
Communication through one-to-one conversation in different social contexts
Learning Korean etiquettes in different social settings
Practicing different Korean verb endings according to the social contexts (e.g. at home/school /work, etc.) and different relationship with the interlocutors (e.g. close friends /parents /colleagues at work, etc.)
Learning a variety of lexical items used in spoken language, such as commonly used idioms, abbreviations, slangs, dialects and so on
Thinking about communication strategies on how to compensate one's linguistic knowledge breakdown
Role-playing with learned contents to improve speaking skills
Communication through Discussions
Reading a variety of stories and articles posted on Blackboard. Students are expected to complete the readings prior to the class in which they are discussed.
Learning how to express one's own opinions
(topics: differences between Korean traditional and contemporary culture)
Learning how to discuss efficiently
Learning how to support and oppose one's opinions.
Communication through Presentation
Learning useful expressions used in presentation
Learning how to improve presentation skills
Learning how to cope with insufficient linguistic knowledge

courses.subject: KORE
courses.title: Creative Writing in Korean
courses.description: This course aims to improve students’ creative writing skills in Korean. It includes a systematic review on the grammar of Korean language and various activities for students to practice their writing skills. In each writing task, students will recognize their personal writing style and reduce common mistakes by receiving peer evaluation and the teacher’s feedback. Also, students will create a portfolio to keep track of their writing progress. This course encourages students to build confidence in writing, explore different writing skills, and produce texts align with them.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Prerequisites: KORE3001,3002 or 3051
Not for students who have taken KORE3100 in 2nd term 2019-20
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, students should be able to
(1) comprehend, identify, interpret, analyse and evaluate ideas from diverse texts.
(2) write coherent texts using lexico-grammatical choices appropriate to the task
(3) improve writing skills by analyzing frequent and common mistakes
(4) evaluate critically their own and the other’s written materials
courses.course_syllabus:
Topic
Content
Culture
1. Preparation for Korean Writing
- Introduction to the course.
- Instruction about the squared manuscript paper and spacing rules
- Grammar review
- Korean Wave in Hong Kong
- Trend of travelling and leisure in Korea
- Students’ campus life in Korea
- Positive and negative aspect of the private tutoring in Korea
2. Important skills
for Korean Writing
- Understanding the general structure of texts
- Elaborating sentence structures
- Correcting errors of the given texts
- Completing the logical flow
- Writing process
3. Strategies for different types of writing
&
Creative Writing
- Narrative essay
- News Report
- Reflective essay
- Script of Drama or Movie

courses.subject: KORE
courses.title: Business Korean
courses.description: This course introduces learners of Korean to useful vocabulary and essential communicative skills in a Korean-speaking business environment. The topics are organized in language functions such as writing business emails, giving business presentations, and conducting and attending job interviews. Sufficient opportunities to enhance the four basic language skills (listening, speaking, reading and writing) in the business setting will be provided. Students will be exposed to a wide range of authentic materials taken from the traditional media and the internet, and participate in a variety of learning activities such as group discussions, role-play tasks and oral presentations. This course highlights cultural factors in the practice of business in Korea and aims to improve corresponding cross-cultural communicative skills therein.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students will be able to:
1. Improve their Korean language abilities in a business context.
2. Understand simple oral and written business messages in Korean.
3. Carry out basic oral and written business conversations in Korean.
4. Respond to a direct exchange of information on familiar and routine business matters in Korean.
5. Demonstrate an increased awareness of the cultural traits of the Korean-speaking society and the differences in intercultural business communications.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week
Unit
Content
Assignment or Text
Week 1
Lesson 1 & 2
Course introduction, finding jobs, writing for self-introduction.
Week 2
Lesson 2 & 3
Speaking in an Interview: vocabulary and expressions to describe yourself.
Week 3
Lesson 3 & 4
Types of units in a company, finding the right place.
Week 4
Lesson 4 & 5
Description on the name card.
worksheet submission
Week 5
Revision
Revision for lessons 1-5.
Week 6
Lesson 5 & 6
Conversation in a meeting.
Week 7
Lesson 6 & 7
How to improve your presentation skills.
worksheet submission
Week 9
Lesson 7 & 8
Writing business e-mails.
Week 10
Lesson 8 & 9
Advertising for gatherings, meetings, ceremonies, etc.
Week 11
Lesson 9 & 10
Company dinner culture
worksheet submission
Week 12
Revision
Revision for lessons 6-10
Week 13
Students’ presentations & feedback
Week 14
Week 15
Final examination
courses.feedback_evaluation: Our language programme highly values students’ feedback for enhancement of teaching and teaching quality. Qualitative feedback from students will be collected in the mid-term course and teaching evaluation (CTE) for teacher’s reference and or self-reflection. A term-end CTE will be conducted to collect both quantitative and qualitative feedback from students. Students are also welcome to give their comments on the course to the course teacher or course level coordinator at any time.

courses.description: This is a summer intensive Korean language course, covering the full syllabus of KORE3001 and 3002.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken KORE3001 or KORE3002. Prerequisite: KORE3000 (2002) or KORE3050 (2010).
courses.course_syllabus: This is a summer intensive Korean language course, covering the full syllabus of KORE3001 and 3002.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Our programme highly values students’ feedback and comments and is happy to use them for reflection on our teaching and improvement. Students are very welcome to provide comments and feedback on the course any time to their course teacher or the course level coordinator through email or in personal conversation. In addition, students’ feedbacks will be collected in the middle of the term through an open-end questionnaire and the teacher will discuss the feedbacks in class and make improvements if necessary. The course will also follow the university’s course evaluation exercise at the end of the term, and students’ feedbacks will be used for future course planning and teaching.
courses.required_readings:
• Seoul University Korean Language Center. ‘Active Korean’. Course book with Audio CD & its Work book
• Sogang University Korean Language Center. ‘Sogang Korean’. Course book with Audio CD & its Work book
• Ewha University Korean Language Center. ‘Ewha Korean’. Course book with Audio CD & its Work book

courses.subject: KORE
courses.title: Korean through Drama
courses.description: This course aims to improve students’ communication skills through Korean multi-media such as TV dramas, movies and songs. It emphasizes the training of listening and speaking skills in authentic everyday situations as they are presented in Korean media, particularly in popular TV dramas. Since the multi-media materials not only provide authentic communication situations but also present real life cultural elements, students will be able to gain a better understanding of many aspects of Korean society while practicing their four language skills. Producing a drama in the middle and the end of the term will be a major assessment method to help students develop their creativity and fluency.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students will be able to
 identify a variety of colloquial expressions used in real life context and use them appropriately.
distinguish the different registers of Korean depending on the level of interpersonal relations and apply the appropriate registers in everyday communicative situations.
 create a short drama in the style of Korean TV dramas using a variety of registers and colloquial expressions.
 build confidence in improvising and spontaneous speech production.

courses.feedback_evaluation:
The evaluation process of the course will be conducted in the following manner:
a. 1 mid-term evaluation and collection of qualitative feedback from student panels/ forums/ internet forums
b. 1 end-of-term course evaluation with statistics and open comments from students regarding the course’s strengths and areas of improvements

courses.subject: KORE
courses.title: Korean through Folktales
courses.description: This course is a combination of content learning and language learning. Making use of famous Korean folktales, students will enrich their understanding of the Korean language as well as their knowledge about Korean folktales and culture. The tales taught will be read in simplified versions in Korean.

courses.subject: KORE
courses.title: Korean through Media
courses.description: This course is designed to help students improve daily conversational skills learned from Korean media such as dramas, news, advertisements, and K-pops. With exposure to various communicative situations through Korean media, students will be able to learn colloquial Korean and different styles of speech while understanding Korean culture and society deeply. This class will provide an opportunity to share students’ learning of media expressions, phrases, and grammar, through classroom activities, assignments, and group projects using their creativity. Students will also be encouraged to take their learning further, scrutinize differences in expressions of Korean media, and discover similarities and differences between Korean media expressions and those from their own countries. All the materials and the medium of instruction will be in Korean.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, students will be able to:
- identify native Korean colloquial expressions used in media and apply them in real-life contexts
- speak, listen to, read, and write using expressions, vocabulary, and sentences from media effectively and recognize the proper usage
- expand the knowledge of Korean culture, society, and customs
- share learned knowledge confidently with other classmates/peers and develop self-learning techniques
- connect expressions from each media with grammar and culture and internalize them in the long run

courses.feedback_evaluation: Our language programme highly values students’ feedback and comments and is happy to use them for reflection on our teaching and improvement. Students are very welcome to provide comments and feedback on the course at any time to their course teacher or the course level coordinator through email or in personal conversation. In addition, students’ feedback will be collected in the middle of the term through an open-ended questionnaire and the teacher will discuss the feedback in class and make improvements if necessary. The course will also follow the university’s course evaluation exercise at the end of the term, and students’ feedback will be used for future course planning and teaching.
courses.required_readings: No textbook is required; videos and notes will be provided in class.

courses.subject: KORE
courses.title: Special Topics in Korean
courses.description: This course aims at furthering students' understanding of selected area(s) of Korean language, literature or culture. Topics will vary from year to year. Offerings with different subtitles can be taken up for credit, up to a maximum of two times.
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the end of this course, students demonstrate the ability to:
- undertake projects that integrate the insights of language and culture studies.
- discuss and analyse language phenomena, literary productions or cultural representations of Korean.
- make use of their linguistic, literary or cultural knowledge to critically assess and evaluate productions and representations in Korean language, literature and culture.
